reviewText:
I don't recommend the game for everyone. Not every game is for everyone.
That being said, if you are here and are looking for a special and unique game, something different, you are in the right place. And I do recommend you this game.

So first I'll tell you why you might not like Kwaan :
It's a very different game, not bad, just different.
And this can be very disturbing for some.
Goals are explained but not really entirely. There is no end game, competition, combat.

The game is all about how to play together to achieve a bigger goal than you could alone.
It's about how to take care of a world with the help of everyone, every day.

Now, why will you love this game ?- Because it's a very different game.
You won't have to fight, or kill or get killed (you can die, but no ennemie here to kill you).

- There is a big learning curve but the other players will be pleased to help you learn.

- The game is beautiful for anyone who loves pixel art. It's cute, and the music is soothing.

- The gameplay is relaxing : you'll have to draw (really) to achieve things or just for the sake of drawing (there is spaces for free drawing, that's a very nice touch). You'll have to explore, and to explore more you'll have to uncover mysteries of the world. Most of things to unlock can't be done alone, and everyone will participate to unlock new regions to explore or new mysteries to uncover.

- You will find some RPG mecanics. You'll gain XP by doing quests. You'll have skill points to spend. You can even customise your dwall (your character) with a cute haat (a leaf or a flower as a hat :p). And you have skill to use but in KWAAN your skills are dancing, eating, meditating, singing !

- KWAAN is a living world that needs to be taken care of ! Create bunnies so you can have flowers ! Those flowers will create butterflies ! (it's just an example of the ecosystem, but there is a LOT to learn on how life is working on KWAAN).
There is a story to discover and I won't say much more, to not spoil but also because I haven't uncover all the story myself.

- The developpers are very active and you will find them online a lot.
Sometimes you will be able to tell them about a bug and they will just work on it right away.
As it's an online game only, the devs will continue to work on KWAAN for some time to keep the world and the stories alive.

But for that to happen we need players...
So come ! Don't be shy ! You might not know it but this game is perfect for you ;)
voteText: 66 of 71 people (93%) found this review helpful 4 people found this review funny

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Kwaan is probably the cutest and most peaceful multiplayer game I've ever played, and this is good. I've bumped into this little gem by chance while I was browsing through the steam store in search of some good summer deals. I'm truly glad I found it despite its low visibility.

You play as a Dwaal, a cute sapling; you can't jump, but you can use a rope to swing around the world (or a sheep as a trampoline!). This platform element is actually pretty challenging, especially at the very beginning of your experience. The more you play, the more you actually become good with your rope and you'll be able to reach tricky places.
You can collect maana gems and use them to buy items in the shop or as a energy coin to summon critters and bloom flowers.
There are colorful pixels scattered all around the world, and you can use them to draw, to create new branches on the Kwaal tree, to bloom flowers and to grow fruits.
Funny fact: maana crystals are shared among all players!
Every day you unlock new quests to complete in order to gain levels and unlock new summoning abilities.

The main goal of the game is to please the big tree Kwaal and make him fell happy with everyday rituals, in order to keep the world alive. Rituals may consist in summoning new creatures, crafting items and dancing all together for Kwaal.

The music is very charming and catchy, and the world is so bright and cheerful.
What I like the most about this game is actually the community: I met very kind people who teached me what to do and how to. Kwaal is in fact a very cooperative game, in order to complete the daily ritual you need the help of other players (and you really have more fun dancing with other people rather than alone!).

There are currently two servers: a FR one and a US East one. You can play on both since you won't lose your progress after switching from a server to another. On the FR server people speak English as well, so I got no communication issues. The community is still pretty small yet very active; everytime I log in, there are progressions on the daily ritual.

Despite being still an early access, the game is really polished and I didn't notice any game-breaking bug yet.
All in all, I definitely recommend Kwaan and I truly hope the community will grow bigger, this game really deserves it.

reviewText: I have had this game for a couple of weeks and it's fascinating. It evolves around the idea of the playerbase (the dwaals) gathering offerings for KWAAN's (the tree) three-step ritual, so that it maintains its happiness and keeps on surviving for another day. Every few succeeded rituals, KWAAN becomes taller and allows for more room for climbing, drawing, putting up fruit, and most importantly, more Taazes (quest lines). If the playerbase neglects KWAAN's need of rituals, it becomes progressively unhappier to the point where the server dies and everything is reset.\n\nThe ritual consists of a set number of dwaals dancing (a number that increases with every step, from 4 to 6 to 8) in front of the altar after gathering the previously mentioned offerings (which may be animals such as beavers, sheep, butterflies, koalas). The act of completing a ritual's third step, and thus finishing all requirements for KWAAN to survive, is known as Kwaanza"

reviewText:
Early Access Review

For once - a pacifistic multiplayer game.
You play a humanoid sapling whose main concern is to finish today's ritual, have some fun and please Kwaan.
Controls are very simple. You click with your mose and your character runs to that place. There is also some platforming involved and some of it is not very simple. For that you use a rope and it can be especially tricy when there are spikes around.
Activities consist of random summoning of criters depending on your needs. There is flower blooming (you draw flowers pixel by pixel) and also painting (there are pictures throughout the world that anyone can edit).
Main issue is there is not enough players sometimes and some rituals are imposible to do solo. Especially when you're a new player and can't get enough exp in one day (you get xp by completing daily quests).
I am excited to see how this game turns out but Ankama should try to attract more players since this game - if you want to really have fun with it needs larger community than it is now.
If you want to support sort of unique project buy this game but take note that this is still very early access.
voteText: 20 of 21 people (95%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Being a gamer for over 2 decades I've played thousands of games from various genres. Although one genre that never intrigued me to touch was MMOs. Maybe cause most of them were fantasy and had frustrating menus and thousand HUDs. So what happened here?
Well to tell you the truth, the artstyle of KWAAN played a major part to drag me in. Then I saw that your main goal is to keep alive a tree-server. Also there was a pixel editor kinda thing and  I think that was the last piece that made me push the add to cart button.
As I'm in game for a few days now, I found that the game has a unique way to unravel it's gameplay and the community plays a major part on that too. There are some minor 'everyday' missions to do to get XP and some puzzle missions that you have to squish your brain to solve them (or just ask for tips from the lovely people in there).
Yes the game is weird. Maybe that's why I like it. Are you weird enough?

More or less this is my review. Funny game with a lot of things to do, nice people, and for sure developers will add more things soon.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I'm glad I got to stop by the booth and test it out at PAX East 2015! It lead me to get this game right away at it's release in Steam's Early Access soon thereafter!

A delightfully designed game! It's an adventure MMO co-op game, yet it's even has good dynamics for singularly leisure play when you just want to try and figure out the puzzles and gameplay basics by yourself. There's a great community of people always willing to help out when you are stuck or confused at gameplay. Everyone is helpful and friendly. Yet you've got to work together to allow Kwaan to grow and thrive. Makes the game more enjoyable to get everyone involved.

The game is still in Steam Early Access. But it's a good thing. Devs like to hear and grow and develop from our input on the forums. And with this we frequently get updates to gameplay every few weeks.

Quite enjoyable. Highly recommended even in it's early stages.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

In a world where you are expected to action platform with extreme pinpoint precision all the while only being able to click to move, we bring you KWAAN! A game about trying to figure out how to play the game!

In this game you're required to complete random tasks each day around the world or else THE SERVER DIES! Normally you would work togeather to solve the mysteries of the world and save the day, but no one plays! Can you figure out how to stop the world from dying and end all suffering for one more day all by yourself!?! No, no you cannot! But you sure can try for 25 minutes then uninstall and refund the game.

reviewText: So far I'm really impressed with KWAAN.  I didn't really know what to expect.  The art style is really cute, and I love the pixel editor aspect of the game.  I think I spent my first hour just editing and gathering pixels.  I also liked that each time i logged in it was a different world.  Everyone kind of bands together to build the different building and move forward in the story.  Movement was a little tricky since you can't jump.  But I think the grappling hook aspect helped make things more challenging and fun.  Ultimately the puzzle aspect is what is going to draw you in.  It's a game where you actually use your mind instead of mindlessly hacking and slashing away at things.  Definitely fun!
voteText: 7 of 10 people (70%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Early Access Review

KWAAN In A Nutshell: Great Game!
This is an Early Access game, so there is still a lot to be done, but taking in from the time I have played this game, I can say that it is very promising. What I like the most about this game so far is that it requires the players to actually cooperate! Very few MMOs I have played actually do this in the way KWAAN does. Even though the co-op is limited to dancing and summoning crits, I know the devs are working on new content. This brings me to another plus to this game: the devs actually LISTEN to what players have to say! Talk to them and suggest new things! They actually want to make this game better. With all this being said, I really enjoy this game, even though not many people are playing at a time. I can tell that this game will go far and I'm very glad I bought it! Worth every cent and more. :)

reviewText:
Early Access Review

KWAAN is a very cute, server coop game.  I've enjoyed figuring things out, finding places and things, and working with the community on my server.  This game is all about working together, and that makes everyone willing to help.  We have a great community going on the US East server, and I've already made some great friends.

If figuring out gameplay basics isn't your thing, you can read the tutorial here, or just ask players in game.  Everyone is so helpful and friendly!

There are a few little glitches here and there, but I've found that the devs pay attention to the feedback on the forums, and things have been fixed, usually in under 24 hours.  That is an amazing turn around time.

The content right now is a bit limited.  However, it is an early release game.  I can't wait to find the little things that get added.  Finding a new spot to make pixel art is really cool.  The things people come up with on flowers, or in the trees in spectacular.  Drop in, check it out, and say hi!

reviewText:
Kwaan is an intresting mix of RPG'ish features, platformer and adventure type elements where you get to control a
character known as a 'Dwaal' and go around a pixel game world doing stuff and I mean alot of interesting stuff.

This game comes pretty close visually comparatively with Starbound and Terraria although the art style has it's own distinct originality and let me say it is gorgeous!.

Alot is going down under this game, you've basically got features of an RPG hidden plain outright such as crafting and summoning (really reminded me alot of Starbound). The platformer type gameplay fits this game just perfectly and the game world is actually pretty strange (in a good way) and is really entertaining with it's quirky characters (other than the online players).

PROS :-
Visually pleasing and relaxing art style.
Beautiful game world (very important in a ♥♥♥♥♥♥me).
Intresting game mechanics
(crating,summoning,building stuff and it has a really cool way in which you have to grow stuff using a puzzle like element).
Good servers (no crashes or anything).
Alot of stuff to do so you'll never bore easily.
You actually need to work with other players in order to build stuff as it's easier to collect the building materials then (important in a ♥♥♥♥♥♥me)
Controls work awesome considering it's only the mouse you have to use!.

CONS :-
A bit hard at first to figure out all the strange things going on (will get used to it after awhile).
No map or arrows to direct you to your goal (not much of an issue).

This game is pretty intresting in it's use of different concepts and ideas making for an enjoyable experience.
Currently not many players are on the servers and I'm sure as this game grows and more players join in it'll provide a really enjoyable and fun experience!.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Kwaan hits the retina with its absolute eye candiness : colorful, vibrant lively and über cute, you just want to wander around and appreciate its little world.
Definitely not a game that will take by the hand abut if accept to get lost, meet the inhabitants, explore the ecosystem and the rules will appear little by little.

A perfect 15 min daily holiday with crabs and rabbits, a ritual to start the day by enjoying a delicately crafted world and meeting newcomers...
Truly a adorable gem, shiny and heartwarming.

reviewText:
here's the thing: I love this game. It's very casual and calming not to mention so so cute, others before me have definitely covered the basics of gameplay and the concept driving the world of kwaan so I don't want to delve too deep into that, but I do want to say that I love love love the idea of sustaining a little world by working together. That's what melts my heart: being able to take a little part of your day to care for a small (digital) corner of the world through teamwork. Even if everything else goes wrong that day it's a little thing that can go right.

There are more 'how to play' basics available than when I first got the game which makes it a bit less confusing when you first get started, but even that you have to work to figure out how the world works and discover the uses of items (all with the help of your dwaal friends) strengthens the inner logic of the game and really makes it your world to discover.

The graphics are unbelievably adorable, the music changes as you go through the cycles of kwaan's day and I personally find it so soothing and uplifting, and the community is so kind and supportive. The one thing that's been troubling me is that the structure of this game depends on there being players in the game and lately people have been going on less and less; it can be disheartening to go in and find that you're playing all by yourself! The community is pretty small as it is so it's really noticable when dwaals go MIA. Sooooooo! the best solution is for all you kind folks to get the game and join in in our quest to please Kwaan, our tree god :)
voteText: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Early Access Review

KWAAN is an interesting specimen. Not quite a platformer, not entirely an RPG, the game occupies a space between the two genres, and throws in the concepts of ecosystemic servers and communal gameplay.

All in all, a simple, peaceful little game that should be perfect for a bit of time away from the usual offerings. What takes Kwaan a step away from perfection are the few problems that bog down what could be a really great example of non-violent, social game experiences.

The biggest of these is the control scheme. Your player character is controlled with the mouse. A click near the character moves it left and right, and a click on an object higher up will allow the player to swing towards the object, while holding pulls the character closer to said object. I’m sure this was created with fluidity and freedom in mind, but it simply does not work. Clicking to move in a sidescrolling environment is incredibly counter-intuitive, and unless the developers offer to rewire the brains of their customers, feels anything but natural. Reaching higher places can be a frustrating business, and even walking onto platforms is made unnecessarily annoying, often resulting in falling off and having to start over again.

Adding a traditional keyboard control scheme, or even a keyboard/mouse combination, would make for a much more enjoyable experience.

Another major issue of the game is the overwhelming amount of words and concepts the game throws at you. Words like taaz, zaaz, miaam and paash are used in dialogue and menus with little or no explanation, and the game makes no effort to ease new players into its world, systems and mythology. I know the developers are working on a tutorial and story mode, but I think an internal, constantly updating codex or handbook is the best option for handling the huge amount of…stuff in this game. Getting into the game can be difficult. Since there is no tutorial, players have to rely on more experienced players, which is not always possible, due to constant server underpopulation. As of now, the KWAAN wiki, the only other place for help, is equally underpopulated, and not much help.

Other than that, KWAAN is a good game but wobbles dangerously into bad game territory when it comes to certain design and gameplay decisions. The pixel artwork is stunning to look at, not to mention the amazing user-created art that populates the game world. But while pixelated images are nice to look at, pixelated text is quite the opposite, making in-game reading a chore. The NPCs are cute and the things they say are funny, but we know absolutely nothing about any of them, and the somewhat philosophical quips scattered around the game and related media can feel a tiny bit pretentious when you’re given no reason to really care about the world.

KWAAN is still in early access, though, and the developer promises a tutorial and story mode, among other improvements. Whether I keep playing is up to whether the developer can fix the flawed controls and maybe tone down on the mythology, at least at the beginning. And, for a game that (literally) lives and dies on its community, a few more players sure would be nice.

reviewText: Game looked really cute and adorable so added it to my wishlist. Was gifted the game, installed it only to log in and sit there unable to play. Out of confusion I looked around only to find that the Devs edited the level needed to join the servers to play to a higher number. All you can do for level 1-4 is just stare at the server list. Apparently every so often when they remember, they change the number of players to allow more people.\n\nEdit: So yamato was nice enough to give me a copy after that review. I've been giving this game a chance and it's pretty fun even if I don't get everything done/understand what I'm doing. It's fun trying to figure out the puzzles and I hope more is added in later.

reviewText: One of the most interesting and creative indie games i've ever played. At first it's hard to know what's going on but the community is great at helping out and the more you play the more you learn how the world of KWAAN operates. There are different missions to complete and you need to work out everything by solving the clues that you come across. There will be others in the game who are also trying to solve the same mission and it's great solving it together. Highly recommended

reviewText:
Hey guys, Csgoallan here.

Today I'm going to be reviewing Kwaan. Kwaan is an amazing game but it's not your average game!

You can't kill anything in Kwaan. Instead, you progress through the game by helping others. You also can't really achieve anything alone, and so you must want to work together with other people.

That being said, if you're a community driven type of person, this game is definitely for you. Because everyone here is so nice. The game just gives such positive vibes with it's cute art style and relaxing music. The positivity is contagious. The developers are also very active and whenever you need help with something, they'll get back to you within a heartbeat.

The community's a bit small at the moment but it's slowly growing. So we'd love to have you!
voteText: 7 of 13 people (54%) found this review helpful

reviewText: I don't even know where to begin. Well, for starters, the game revolves around fetch quests. There's not much to it besides walking from place to place, and summoning animals. Summoning animals sounds really fun, but for starters, it centers around waiting for fruits or sticks or whatever. And it doesn't really do much of anything besides getting rid of walls, it seems. Not only that, but most things in the game aren't really hinted at or anything. Items don't have descriptions, Locked doors don't tell you how to unlock them... apparently, you're supposed to just ask the chat what to do at every turn. There's no way to figure out what you're supposed to do, you just ask what to do at EVERY obstacle. That's it. That's the WHOLE game. I don't think I've seen a worse idea for a game in my life. Not to mention, the only character customization is changing your hat, and the only sandbox" element is drawing on the tree or on some signs."
